title: 115_hr2565
content: SECTION 1. USE OF REPLACEMENT COST IN DETERMINING PREMIUM RATES. The Administrator of FEMA will conduct a study to evaluate best practices for risk rating in flood insurance, assess options for including replacement cost value in premium rate estimates, and provide recommendations for incorporating replacement cost value in risk premium rates. The Administrator of FEMA will evaluate best practices for risk rating in flood insurance, assess options for incorporating replacement cost value in premium rate estimates, and develop an implementation plan with a timeline for including replacement cost value in risk premium rates. A report must be submitted to the Committee on Financial Services within 12 months of the enactment of the Act. The report to be submitted to the Committee on Financial Services and the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs will include an analysis of study recommendations, actions taken by the Administrator to implement recommendations, and a description of the study. The report will include an analysis of study recommendations, actions taken by the Administrator, and a description of any deferred or unacted upon recommendations. Additionally, changes to premium rates incorporating replacement cost value will be implemented. The amendments to flood insurance coverage under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 shall incorporate replacement cost value and be effective after a 12-month period from the enactment of the Act. The Administrator of FEMA will gradually apply these amendments to properties in different geographic regions in the US until December 31, 2020. The amendments to flood insurance coverage under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 will be phased in geographically throughout the United States as sufficient information becomes available. After a 12-month period, these amendments will apply to all flood insurance coverage.
